question.title: Switch between decompiles and source code in IntelliJ
question.body:
I work at an organization that has several Java Spring backend services (for example, CRUD_service) as well as one common library, common which all of the services depend on. When debugging in the CRUD_service repo, I often need to set breakpoints on lines that are part of common. Since common is a different project, IntelliJ has to decompile common files as .class files, which changes the formatting of the code compared to the source, and occasionally leads to "byte code and source code out of sync" issues.

I discovered that in IntelliJ, you can go to File -> Project Structure -> Modules, then import common as a module, and add it as a module dependency of CRUD_service. However, I ALSO want to be able to use the code from the .jar file referenced in my pom.xml (in order to access specific versions of common that are stored locally). Ideally I would have two separate configs or profiles, one which points to the source code, and one which uses the compiled code, and be able to easily switch back and forth between these different profiles. Is there any way to do this, either through IntelliJ or Maven? I've seen similar questions to this one, but nothing regarding switching back and forth dynamically between the two. Thanks!

question_comments.body: Ich need to debug a library that is created in-house make sure the commons-project also releases the sources jar. Then you don't need a decompiler and in addition have access to the source code comments. Maven/Gradle allow to automatically build and deploy source artifacts the same way compiled artifacts are build and deployed.

You know in Intellij that for many libraries (including Spring) you can click a “download sources” to get the actual source code - which therefore means getting the JavaDoc, etc. this is because maven itself handles the packing. I believe the plug-in to do this is : maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/examples/…
